page.title: 03CUSTOMS AND LANGUAGE
page.content: The{Molly Carr Wood Sing}was started in l9OO by Zion Methodists. On Whit Sunday mornings, people walk through the bluebells in the wood, and sing hymns. A count is taken and breakfast is served after the sing. {Local dialect} People say the Yorkshire dialect is dying out. Only the old ones still know many dialect words. These words go back hundreds of years, before modern English was spoken. Here are just a few we know (we have not seen them written down, so the spelling is based on the sound): addle - to earn; agait - doing, going; baht - without; brass - money; fettle - to clean (n. in good condition); happen - perhaps; lake - to play; mither - to bother; oss -to move, to try; poise - to kick.
